msDesc.head: Letter from Maria Edgeworth to Mrs. Miles, , October 10, 1814

editorialDecl.p: Edgeworth’s spelling and punctuation are retained in transcription, including non-standard spelling, line breaks, and hyphenation of words. The long s and ligatured forms are silently emended.

div.p:
Inclosed I send a draft
for ten pounds - Out of
which I should be much
obliged to you if you would
pay >Miss Farrell the amount
of her account enclosed and
take a settled at the bottom of
her account - Give her also
the enclosed note which I
have written expressly to re
proach reproach her with sending the
dresses in a box to Ireland in
stead of sending them to you as
had been desired & I have request
ed requested that she will never do so
in the future.

The balance of the ten pound
Which will remain after
Miss Farrell is paid I request
My dear Madam you will
be so kind to keep in your
hands to pay for any commis
sions commissions with which I may trouble
you - Though Mr. Miles is so
very obliging to me, or rather
because he is so obliging to me
I wish to avoid calling upon
him & plaguing him upon
very trifling occasion. - I in
close inclose with many thanks a
draft for the £2..14..0. which
Line out of place
he paid Mrs. Moutray for me

I regret that he was not in
the way when Mrs. Moutray &
her daughter called as they
are two of the most amiable
& charming of our friends, whom
I should have been proud that
he should have seen & whom
I am sure he would have been
pleased to see

Quite at your leisure when
you are looking for any thing
at a haberdashers for yourself
will you get for me 6 yards
of ribbon same as the pattern
of ribbon which you bought
for me - If the color matches
I do not mind what the pattern
may be as I want it for sashes
for my sasnet gown of this color

I rejoice to hear that you
like the continuation of Early Lessons
the most agreeable compliments
we ever have or ever shall receive
are those which we are sometimes
so fortunate to hear from really
good mothers who are interestd
upon the education of their children

Pray if the Robins petition or the
songs in the Knapsack have been set to
music make Mrs. Miles sent them to
me as a Christmas box for one of my
little sisters (Sophy) who has an agreeable
voice & will take pleasure & pride in
singing them to my father
div.closer:
I am dear Madam
Sincerely yours
Maria Edgeworth
Excuse my mistake
in tearing this paper

postscript.p:
Mrs. Miles
I will further trouble you to
buy for me a dozen gilt clothes
such as are used for bracelets or
any kind that will fasten a cloth
pelisse - they will not be seen as
they will fasten it within side
so that I shall think more of the
goodness of the catch than of the beauty
- Mrs. Miles will soon send a packet
under a government frank but
do not send them in that because I
have promised not to do so - wait till
some member of parliament can frank
them - they will come safely between
two cards in one or two common franks
